channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 10
item.description: AMC CEO Adam Aron, sang a cautious tune after his company, which got clobbered by the pandemic but staged a furious, individual investor-led comeback, beat revenue expectations last quarter. (Slate)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: NASA Is Looking for Human Guinea Pigs for Simulated Mars Mission
item.description: If you want to get away from it all—Covid, climate change, people who just text “hey”—NASA is giving you an opportunity to live on Mars for a year. If not, we hear Richard Branson is selling tickets to space for $450,000 a pop.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Car Rental Industry Rebounds As the Economy Rockets Out of the Pandemic
item.description: The greatest Covid comeback story: Hertz went bankrupt last June at the peak of the pandemic, weighed down by nearly $19 billion in debt, and roughly 700,000 cars parked with no one to drive them.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Democrats Announce $3.5 Trillion Budget Plan
item.description: It will address... The budget will require the backing of every Democrat in the 50-50 Senate, plus the tie breaking vote of VP Kamala Harris, to pass. Where will the money come from? The plan didn’t include lifting the debt ceiling, which would allow Uncle Sam to keep on borrowing to fund the spending.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: The new office politics? An ‘existential crisis’ for some
item.description: Lat speaks about a law firm that recently decreed employees must return to the office five days a week, only to be met with staff reaching out en masse to recruiters for jobs elsewhere. You may have heard of this described as the “hybrid” work environment, where some people work from home and others log on from a corporate office. The idea that office politics are winnable? “That might not be a bad thing because there are a lot of artificial deadlines of, ‘I want this on my desk first thing in the morning’ by bosses who, lo and behold, don’t read that until the afternoon or the next day,” he says.  The shift to a virtual workplace was hard on office politics, too, particularly in hidebound industries like finance and law where remote work was relatively rare before the pandemic. For example, some workers are easing their sense of urgency around work projects, Lat notes, because it proved to be a charade all along. What I’ve seen and heard from workers is that now, when a manager steps in, they’re actually getting in the way of work.” “The invisible work women have always done is finally being recognized and appreciated because men had to experience it,” says Dawn Bovasso, a freelance creative director in Boston who has written about workplace policies’ effects on women. “The old way was really exclusive, excluding a lot of people: people of color, women, the differently abled—a lot of people,” she says.  If the performative politics of pre-pandemic office life are a bowl of ice cream, the pandemic surely melted it. “This new way is going to be inclusive. If the corporate world’s reaction to the COVID-19 pandemic turned 2020 into a mad scramble for new protocols defined by adaptive office tools like Google Docs, Slack, and Zoom, then its adjustment to a tentative recovery suggests a partial return to the office and semi normalcy. “A lot of office politics is over stupid stuff and a lot of that stupid stuff is tied to the physical environment: fighting over the corner office, talking so loudly on calls that coworkers can hear them down the hall, being bad at bathroom etiquette, vaping at your desk, leaving smelly food in the break room,” he says. The virtual environment has undoubtedly given workers more power over their supervisors. “It is challenging to replicate office politics in a virtual era, which isn’t a bad thing,” says David Lat, a longtime analyst of law firm culture and himself a former top-tier recruiter. “So much of politics arises from physical interaction, so if we have less interaction we have less cause for conflict and less need for politics.” True, the completely virtual environment that many people have been working in for 17 months has hardly been a cakewalk.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: The Week Ahead: August 9
item.description: , respectively, will reveal the extent of price increases in July for consumers and businesses. This week’s slate of earnings reports includes meme stock AMC, SoftBank, Coinbase, eBay, Wendy’s, Disney, Palantir, DoorDash, and Airbnb. Prepare accordingly.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 9
item.description: Nearly 80% of US workers now earn a minimum of $15/hour, compared to 60% in 2014. Read: What do you do with a billion grams of surplus weed?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Senate Debates Crypto Provision That Opponents Say Would Harm Industry in US
item.description: The goal is to use the $28 billion raised through tighter crypto regulation to help pay for the infrastructure bill. Tucked in to the $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill is a provision that expands the definition of a crypto “broker,” and increases reporting requirements by those brokers to the IRS.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Apple Gets Praised, Blasted for New Scanning Feature
item.description: Apple’s scanning technology is part of a larger suite of child protection features that Apple will roll out with its new mobile operating system, iOS 15, next month. The company said its new technology, called NeuralHash, will scan US iPhones for images of child sexual abuse that have also been uploaded to iCloud.  Looking ahead...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: By the Numbers
item.description: From the moving family watch party videos to the thrusting Australian swim coach, the Tokyo Olympics gave us all a desperately needed distraction while raising thorny questions about the future of the Games. 113: The number of total medals the US won at the Olympics, 25 more than second-place China. 42%: The decrease in viewership from the 2016 Rio Olympics to the Tokyo Games through Tuesday. Team USA also made a last-second comeback to grab the most number of gold medals at the Games, 39 to China’s 38.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Seven Charts That Explain the Current State of Crypto
item.description: Coinbase Falters After Milestone Public Offering  On April 14, 2021, the crypto exchange Coinbase became the first major crypto company to go public in the US, in what many considered a watershed moment for the industry. What institutional investors see in crypto While they remain skeptical about whether crypto has any practical use, institutional investors increasingly think digital assets have a place in an investment portfolio. Producing bitcoin requires a lot of energy Cryptocurrency, and bitcoin specifically, is criticized over the huge amount of energy used in bitcoin mining (environmental concerns is why Elon Musk decided to stop allowing bitcoin payments for Tesla several months ago. Size of the crypto market Total cryptocurrency market capitalization, or the value of all cryptocurrencies in existence, peaked in May 2021 at about $2.4 trillion, up from around $200 billion in 2019. Over $81 million of crypto has been already paid to ransomware addresses so far this year, according to Chainalysis.
item.author: Colleen McFall

item.title: The Week Ahead: August 9

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: By the Numbers
item.description: From the moving family watch party videos to the thrusting Australian swim coach, the Tokyo Olympics gave us all a desperately needed distraction while raising thorny questions about the future of the Games. 113: The number of total medals the US won at the Olympics, 25 more than second-place China. 42%: The decrease in viewership from the 2016 Rio Olympics to the Tokyo Games through Tuesday. Team USA also made a last-second comeback to grab the most number of gold medals at the Games, 39 to China’s 38.

item.title: Kriss Kross: Small Pets
item.author: Mary Tobler

item.title: Money Matters: Navigating Small Business Taxes
item.description: Become one of the first subscribers. Freelancers often open LLCs, which can protect your personal assets from business debt. You might need to make estimated tax payments quarterly. Let a tax pro take it to the finish line for at least the first couple of years. Every expense you incur—from software to coffees with clients—goes in the software. ) Pick one that creates functional invoices, makes inputting expenses easy, and is in your budget.
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 7
item.description: It estimates that 2.5 million weddings will take place next year, compared to an average of 2.1 million weddings/year pre-pandemic and 1.2 million weddings in 2020. ! (The Atlantic)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Dixie Fire Becomes Third-Largest Fire in California History
item.description: The Dixie Fire in California became the third-largest fire in state history yesterday.  Turkey has also suffered from its worst wildfires in decades for the last 10 days. Southern Europe is also burning.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: US Hiring Surges as Employers Add 943,000 Jobs in July
item.description: “I have yet to find a blemish in this jobs report. US employers added 943,000 jobs in July, marking the best monthly performance since August 2020, and the unemployment rate ticked down to 5.4% from 5.9% in June.   The motion picture and sound recording industries had 30.1% fewer jobs in July than in February 2020.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Singapore Goes Ahead With Relaxing Curbs as Countries Learn to Live With Covid
item.description: without new mitigation measures. Compare that to the more lax approach employed by countries like the US and the UK. Why it matters: Singapore is the most significant example yet of a country pivoting from a “Covid Zero” approach to a strategy that accepts Covid as “endemic,” meaning it’s always present but remains at a manageable level. “Living with Covid”Before its pivot, Singapore was part of a group of Asia-Pacific countries that played Whac-A-Mole to snuff out any trace of the coronavirus in an approach known as “Zero Covid.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 7
item.description: It estimates that 2.5 million weddings will take place next year, compared to an average of 2.1 million weddings/year pre-pandemic and 1.2 million weddings in 2020. ! (The Atlantic)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Money Matters: Navigating Small Business Taxes
item.description: Become one of the first subscribers. Freelancers often open LLCs, which can protect your personal assets from business debt. You might need to make estimated tax payments quarterly. Every expense you incur—from software to coffees with clients—goes in the software. —HaleyBefore taking on clients, you’ll need to form a legal business, which matters in part because your structure determines how you’re taxed. ) Pick one that creates functional invoices, makes inputting expenses easy, and is in your budget.
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: US Hiring Surges as Employers Add 943,000 Jobs in July
item.description: Still, the US economy remains 5.7 million jobs short of where it was pre-pandemic, and jobs in some industries may never come back...  “I have yet to find a blemish in this jobs report. Motion picture and sound recording industries had 30.1% fewer jobs in July than in Feb 2020.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.description: Compare that to the more lax approach employed by countries like the US and the UK. without new mitigation measures. Why it matters: Singapore is the most significant example yet of a country pivoting from a “Covid Zero” approach to a strategy that accepts Covid as “endemic,”  which means it’s always present but remains at a manageable level. “Living with Covid”Before its pivot, Singapore was part of a group of Asian-Pacific countries that played Whac-A-Mole to snuff out any trace of the coronavirus in an approach known as “Zero Covid.”

item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Make It Work: I'm a Little Lost
item.description: The first thing you should ask yourself is whether it’s a specific aspect of your current job that you dislike, or if it’s the line of work that you find unfulfilling. Most people who haven’t found a job that they are passionate about have stopped looking for one. Pick up a book on something you know nothing about (the Brew has a whole shelf full of recs). I don't like my current job but I have no idea what I would rather do instead. Some of the most interesting 40-year-olds still don’t.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Shein is the Fastest-Growing E-commerce Company You’ve Maybe Never Heard Of
item.description: Now that you’re listening, here’s the backgroundShein is an online-only, fast-fashion retailer based in China, with a focus on women’s apparel. Fast fashion 2.0, known as “ultra-fast fashion” and popularized by brands like ASOS and Boohoo, got that process down to a week or two. Shein turns around a new design in as little as three days. As factory production gears up, Shein. If you’re not a Gen Z woman with a penchant for online shopping, you may have never heard of the world’s fastest-growing e-commerce company, Shein. If you are in that demographic, the brand likely follows you around the internet like an overly attached chihuahua. But moving this fast has resulted in Shein breaking things. An in-house design team then sends it to a Shein supplier located in China’s manufacturing hub, Guangzhou.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Icebreakers with...Erika Thompson of Texas Beeworks
item.description: But she’s most famous for documenting her calm bee removal services on TikTok.After strapping into a bee suit, we asked Thompson a few Icebreakers—but please, don’t try this at home. I was in orchestra, I was the captain of my high school bowling team, and I loved Star Wars. Then, one day I was sitting at work at my office job and I opened my email and saw a note from Jeopardy! And then after many, many other things, I'm putting together social content.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Stock Watch: Running Shoes
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 6
item.description: (Oliver Burkeman) Read: The three-or-four-hours rule for getting creative work done.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Mattel Debuts Barbies in Likenesses of Frontline Health Workers
item.description: They all have Barbie dolls in their likenesses. Why it matters: Mattel had been criticized for depicting an unrealistic portrait of womanhood with its original white, blonde doll, which turned 60 in 2019. What does Covid-19 vaccine developer Sarah Gilbert have in common with Beyoncé and Marilyn Monroe?
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: BlackRock, Wells Fargo, and Amazon Latest Companies to Push Back Office Reopenings Due to Delta Surge
item.description: Google and Apple moved their office return to October and Google said that all employees who want to come in will need to be vaccinated. Both banks brought employees back to the office earlier this summer and said this week that they haven’t changed their return-to-work policies.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Biden Calls Pushes Auto Industry Toward Electrification
item.description: Still, the US is behind the global EV curve:Electric cars currently make up just 2% of new auto sales in the US, compared to 6% in China and 10% in Europe.  In a show of solidarity with the White House, the automakers pledged to make electric vehicle sales 40%–50% of their total by 2030... Biden’s goal is to cut emissions by 50% below 2005 levels by the end of the decade, and to do that he’s targeting transportation, the industry accounting for 29% of all US emissions.
item.author: Neal Freyman
